title: How to Get Rid of a Hard Pimple

steps.title: Use an ice pack to reduce pain and swelling.
steps.content: Use an ice pack to reduce pain and swelling. When you notice a pimple forming, wrap an ice cube in a light towel and apply it to your skin for at least 10 minutes. Repeat this process 2-3 times a day. [2] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your pimple has become a whitehead, you can also apply a warm compress. Soak a clean washcloth in very warm water, then apply it to your pimple for 10-15 minutes. Repeat this process 3-4 times a day until the pimple releases its pus and heals. [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Apply benzoyl peroxide to your pimple.
steps.content: Apply benzoyl peroxide to your pimple. Most drugstores offer products with 2.5% benzoyl peroxide for over-the-counter use. [4] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source After washing your face, use your fingers to apply a thin layer of gel onto your pimple and let it absorb. [5] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Use benzoyl peroxide on your skin 1-2 times a day. [6] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source Benzoyl peroxide works by reducing the amount of bacteria on the surface of your skin. [7] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source As a peroxide product, benzoyl peroxide can bleach your hair, clothes, towels, and bedding. [8] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Keep it away from your clothing, and consider sleeping on white sheets or towels if you’re applying it before bed.

steps.title: Spread adapalene gel on your acne.
steps.content: Spread adapalene gel on your acne. Adapalene gel is an over-the-counter retinoid that stops pimples from forming under the surface of your skin. [9] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Apply a pea-sized amount of 0.1% adapalene gel onto your pimple once a day, preferably at bedtime. The gel will clear out your pores and reduce inflammation from acne. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Use a product with salicylic acid.
steps.content: Use a product with salicylic acid. Salicylic acid is another proven method to unclog pores and remove sebum and oils that can cause pimples. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Drugstores offer over-the-counter salicylic acid products in concentrations of 0.5% to 2%. [12] X Research source Follow the instructions on the product label to see how often you should apply the treatment. [13] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Higher concentrations of salicylic acid products are available up to 60%, but only by prescription. Higher over-the-counter concentrations are likely to produce more noticeable side effects, such as irritation, burning, or peeling of the skin. [14] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source

steps.title: Wash your face and other affected areas twice a day.
steps.content: Wash your face and other affected areas twice a day. Use your fingertips to apply a mild facial cleanser, and gently rub it on your face in a circular motion. [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Try not to scrub your face or harshly exfoliate it. This can cause permanent scarring and your skin will take longer to heal. [16] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Avoid washing your face much more than twice a day, since this can dry out your skin. Wash your face once in the morning and once before bed, and after you sweat or exercise. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Look for a cleanser labeled as “non-comedogenic.” This means that the product does not cause blackheads or whiteheads. [18] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Harsh soaps and cleansers can dry out your skin and make you more prone to acne. Opt for gentle cleansers, and switch to another product if you get rashes or other negative reactions. [19] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Nodules form when your pores become blocked, usually if your skin produces too much sebum or you don’t clean your skin properly. Keeping your face and body clean can decrease the amount of sebum and cell debris that are at the root of pimples. [20] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Cut out foods from your diet that have a lot of sugar.
steps.content: Cut out foods from your diet that have a lot of sugar. High-glycemic (high sugar) foods have been shown to lead to inflammation and the build-up of bacteria associated with acne. [21] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Dairy products can also affect some people this way. [22] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Changing your diet may lead to a reduction in acne outbreaks. [23] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Foods that are low-sugar include vegetables (like peppers, broccoli, tomatoes, lettuce, and eggplants), fruits (like strawberries, apples, lemons, limes, and pears), legumes (like chickpeas and beans), nuts (like cashews and peanuts), and dark chocolate with more than 70% cocoa. [24] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Consider eliminating sugary soft drinks from your diet and reducing the amount of foods you eat with processed sugar, like candy, donuts, baked goods, and other similar foods. [25] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Get more skin-friendly nutrients to avoid breakouts.
steps.content: Get more skin-friendly nutrients to avoid breakouts. Vitamins A, B, C and D are important for overall skin health. [26] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Omega-3 fats are another nutrient that can help reduce acne due to their anti-inflammatory properties. [27] X Trustworthy Source Oregon State University Linus Pauling Institute Research center dedicated to promoting optimal health through cutting-edge nutrition research and public outreach Go to source Vitamin A rich foods include spinach, carrots, broccoli, red peppers, sweet potatoes, and summer squash. Fruits that contain vitamin A include mangos, cantaloupe, and apricots. Legumes are a good source of vitamin A, as well as meat, and fish, such as herring and salmon. [28] X Research source The easiest way to get Vitamin D is to go out into the sun for 5-30 minutes in the morning or late afternoon at least twice a week. Foods with high levels of vitamin D include fish like salmon and tuna, along with cod liver oil. Vitamin D is also found in dairy, such as milk, yogurt, and cheese. [29] X Research source Omega-3 fatty acids are found in nuts and seeds, such as flaxseeds, flaxseed oil, chia seeds, butternuts, and walnuts. Other great sources for omega-3s are salmon, sardines, mackerel, and whitefish. [30] X Research source Vegetables, like brussel sprouts, spinach, kale, and salad greens, also contain omega-3s. [31] X Research source

steps.title: Steer clear of skin irritants.
steps.content: Steer clear of skin irritants. Wearing tight clothes or using clogging makeup on your skin can make hard pimples worse. These irritants can clog pores or cause irritation. If you do use makeup, make sure to remove it before bed. [32] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Be gentle with your skin.
steps.content: Be gentle with your skin. Roughly touching your skin can cause irritation and make acne worse. Avoid picking at or popping your nodules or cysts, since this can cause flare-ups and lead to longer healing times. [33] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The American Academy of Dermatology also recommends avoiding products that irritate the skin. This includes astringents, toners, and exfoliants. [34] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Use tea tree oil.
steps.content: Use tea tree oil. Tea tree oil is one of the most popular ways to remove hard pimples. It has antiseptic, anti-fungal, antibacterial, and anti-inflammatory properties. [35] X Research source You can apply a small amount of tea tree oil to a cotton round and rub it onto your pimples twice a day, or you can dilute 1-2 drops of tea tree oil in 12 drops of a non-comedogenic carrier oil, such as coconut, jojoba, or olive oil. [36] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you want the tea tree oil to have the consistency of a toner, dilute tea tree oil into witch hazel instead. [37] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Put some tea tree oil on a cotton ball or swab and apply it directly to the deep pimple. If you have a sensitivity to tea tree oil, use a carrier oil. [38] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Tea tree oil may be just as helpful as benzoyl peroxide in treating acne. [39] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Be careful not to get any tea tree oil in or around your mouth. [40] X Trustworthy Source U.S. National Capital Poison Center Independent poison control center providing resources to prevent poisonings and save lives Go to source Tea tree oil can cause sensitivity and rashes for some people, so always test it first. [41] X Research source Put a single drop of the oil on your inner forearm twice daily for 7-10 days. If there’s no skin reaction, you should be able to use the oil. [42] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Try green tea.
steps.content: Try green tea. Studies show that green tea polyphenols may have several properties to help treat acne—it is anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and has been shown to reduce sebum production. [43] X Research source Mix dry green tea leaves with water, then massage the wet leaves into your skin using small, circular motions for 30 seconds. Rinse your face with water when you’re done. [44] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can also make a facial spray with green tea and mineral water to treat minor cuts, sooth sunburns, and reduce swelling. [45] X Research source Alternatively, freeze freshly brewed green tea into ice cubes to use as a toner. After cleansing your face, let the ice thaw slightly and sweep it over your skin. [46] X Research source

steps.title: Apply an herbal mask.
steps.content: Apply an herbal mask. Herbal masks could help reduce the size of hard pimples. Astringent herbs, like white oak’s bark and walnut’s leaf, may kill bacteria and treat acne. [47] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Herbal masks can be made with things in your kitchen, and you can add essential oils if you wish. Begin by mixing 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of raw honey with 1 egg white. Honey has antibacterial, antifungal, and anti-inflammatory properties. [48] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Then, add 0.5 US tbsp (7.4 mL) of peppermint, lavender, calendula, or tea tree, or thyme oil. [49] X Research source Spread the mixture over your face or wherever else you have acne. If you’d like, use a cotton swab to spread the mixture over specific problem areas. Allow the mixture to dry for 15 minutes. Then rinse it off completely with warm water.

steps.title: Make a natural exfoliant for your skin.
steps.content: Make a natural exfoliant for your skin. Exfoliation is often not recommended by many skin specialists because it can irritate your skin. [50] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Scrubbing your face can swell your pores and make acne worse, but a little gentle exfoliation can help keep your skin clear. [51] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Gently exfoliating the skin can remove dead skin cells and prevent them from clogging your pores. [52] X Research source Try the following natural exfoliants that you can make yourself: Make a honey-baking soda exfoliant by mixing 1 teaspoon (5.7 g) of baking soda with 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of honey to form a paste. For an oatmeal exfoliant, combine 1 teaspoon (5.7 g) of finely ground oats, 1 teaspoon (5.7 g) of ground almond meal, 1 teaspoon (5.7 g) of powdered milk, and 0.5 tsp (2.5 mL) to 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of olive, jojoba, vitamin E, avocado, or almond oil. [53] X Research source To make a sugar-coconut oil exfoliant, mix 1 cup (200 g) of sugar with 0.5 (120 mL) of coconut oil. [54] X Research source You can also use castor, jojoba, vitamin E, avocado, or almond oil. Make a sea salt exfoliant by combining 0.5 cup (150 g) of sea salt with 0.25 cup (59 mL) of olive oil. [55] X Research source When using a homemade exfoliant, apply it to your face or any affected areas. Massage your skin in gentle, circular motions for 30 seconds, then rinse with warm water. [56] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Give yourself a steam treatment.
steps.content: Give yourself a steam treatment. Pour hot water into a large bowl, then place a towel over the back of your head. [57] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you like, add 1-2 drops of an essential oil like spearmint, peppermint, lavender, tea tree oil, or calendula to the water. [58] X Research source Close your eyes and lean about 1 ft (30 cm) away from the pot to avoid a steam burn. [59] X Research source Wash your face before steaming and keep your head over the water for 10 minutes at a time, up to 2-3 times a week. The steam will open your pores and soothe your skin. [60] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Pat your face dry after you're done with the treatment and apply a hydrating, non-comedogenic moisturizer. [61] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your acne is on a location other than your face, you can turn your bathroom into a steam shower by using towels to cover gaps below the door and turning on your shower to the highest heat setting. Remove your clothes and sit in the steam for no longer than 15-20 minutes. [62] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source To include essential oils when using your shower as a steam room, add a few drops of oils into a bowl of steaming water. Place a towel over your head and over the bowl of water, then breathe in deeply. [63] X Research source If you begin to feel dizzy while in your bathroom, turn off the shower, leave the room immediately, and drink some cold water to keep you from becoming dehydrated. [64] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Visit your dermatologist.
steps.content: Visit your dermatologist. If you have hard pimples, it’s a good idea to see a dermatologist. They can treat your acne and help prevent scarring. If you have tried over-the-counter products or at-home methods and haven’t seen any improvements, visit your doctor. [65] X Research source

steps.title: Take medicine prescribed by your doctor.
steps.content: Take medicine prescribed by your doctor. This medicine may be able to be used in conjunction with at-home treatments. See your dermatologist to discuss your specific case of acne, medication options available, and any side effects. [66] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Common treatments include retinoids, topical or oral antibiotics, oral contraceptives (for women), isotretinoin, or hormone therapy. [67] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source According to board certified dermatologist Paul Friedman, MD, if you have an isolated acne lesion, “an injection of an intralesional steroid” is one of the quickest ways to clear acne. [68] X Expert Source Paul Friedman, MD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 8 April 2020.

steps.title: Try skin therapy if standard solutions aren’t working.
steps.content: Try skin therapy if standard solutions aren’t working. If you have tried at-home treatments and medication with no success, your doctor may suggest a different treatment. These include: [69] X Research source Lasers and other light therapies: Lasers and light therapies can kill off and reduce bacteria that cause pimples. Chemical peels: These are professional strength chemical peels. Though these are most often used to treat blackreheads and papules, your dermatologist may feel that these can benefit you. Acne removal: This procedure is called drainage and extraction and is used for larger nodules and cysts. It may be an option when the nodules or cysts do not respond to other treatments.
